articles.headline: Look to Airbus for Clues to Sarkozy
articles.snippet: Airbus will provide a test for Nicolas Sarkozy and clarify whether he is a free-market reformer or an economic nationalist.
articles.abstract: Airbus will provide a test for Nicolas Sarkozy and clarify whether he is a free-market reformer or an economic nationalist.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOULOUSE, France, May 7 — For those trying to predict how France’s newly elected president, Nicolas Sarkozy, will lead his country’s economy, one of the first critical tests is likely to come here, at the home base of Airbus, the proud but ailing European plane maker.

articles.headline: Behind the Dow Chemical Firings, a Tangled Corporate Drama
articles.snippet: Two Dow officials, who were fired after the company accused them of conspiring in a buyout, have sued the company for defamation, and Dow has sued them right back.
articles.abstract: Two Dow officials, who were fired after the company accused them of conspiring in a buyout, have sued the company for defamation, and Dow has sued them right back.
articles.lead_paragraph: On March 23, Andrew N. Liveris, the chief executive of Dow Chemical, wrote a scathing performance review about one of his top lieutenants.

articles.headline: Clean Power That Reaps a Whirlwind
articles.snippet: The biggest beneficiary of a U.N. program designed to help poor countries combat global warming has been China.
articles.abstract: The biggest beneficiary of a U.N. program designed to help poor countries combat global warming has been China.

articles.headline: Court Rules for Grasso in Pay Case
articles.snippet: A New York appeals court dismissed four of six legal claims brought against Richard A. Grasso for his compensation.
articles.abstract: A New York appeals court dismissed four of six legal claims brought against Richard A. Grasso for his compensation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Finally, some good news for Richard A. Grasso.

articles.headline: Kansas Tornado Renews Debate on Guard at War
articles.snippet: The governor of Kansas said that the National Guard is struggling to respond to disasters at home.
articles.abstract: The governor of Kansas said that the National Guard is struggling to respond to disasters at home.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, May 8 — For months, Gov. Kathleen Sebelius of Kansas and other governors have warned that their state National Guards are ill-prepared for the next local disaster, be it a tornado, a flash flood or a terrorist’s threat, because of large deployments of their soldiers and equipment in Iraq and Afghanistan.
articles.byline: By Susan Saulny and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Scrutiny Seen of Trading in Dow Jones
articles.snippet: Regulators are expected to examine the role of a Dow Jones director in the possible leak of inside information about Rupert Murdoch’s takeover offer.
articles.abstract: Regulators are expected to examine the role of a Dow Jones director in the possible leak of inside information about Rupert Murdoch’s takeover offer.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal regulators are expected to examine the role of a Dow Jones director in the possible leak of inside information to a Hong Kong couple, who were accused yesterday of making millions of dollars from trading shortly before news of Rupert Murdoch’s takeover offer.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Doctors Reap Millions for Anemia Drugs
articles.snippet: Two drug companies are paying doctors millions to prescribe drugs that regulators say may be unsafe.
articles.abstract: Two drug companies are paying doctors millions to prescribe drugs that regulators say may be unsafe.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two of the world’s largest drug companies are paying hundreds of millions of dollars to doctors every year in return for giving their patients anemia medicines, which regulators now say may be unsafe at commonly used doses.
articles.byline: By Alex Berenson and Andrew Pollack

articles.headline: 6 Men Arrested in a Terror Plot Against Fort Dix
articles.snippet: Six Muslim men had vowed to  attack the base and “kill as many soldiers as possible,” authorities said.
articles.abstract: Six Muslim men had vowed to  attack the base and “kill as many soldiers as possible,” authorities said.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAMDEN, N.J., May 8 —Six Muslim men from New Jersey and Philadelphia were charged Tuesday with plotting to attack Fort Dix with automatic weapons and possibly even rocket-propelled grenades, vowing in taped conversations “to kill as many soldiers as possible,” federal authorities said.

articles.headline: Prenatal Test Puts Down Syndrome in Hard Focus
articles.snippet: A group of parents is trying to present positive perspectives on having a child with Down syndrome.
articles.abstract: A group of parents is trying to present positive perspectives on having a child with Down syndrome.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Sarah Itoh, a self-described “almost-eleven-and-a-half,” betrayed no trace of nervousness as she told a roomful of genetic counselors and obstetricians about herself one recent afternoon.

articles.headline: Opposition Splits While Zimbabwe Slips
articles.snippet: Internecine brawls are evidence that all is not well inside Zimbabwe’s only opposition party of note.
articles.abstract: Internecine brawls are evidence that all is not well inside Zimbabwe’s only opposition party of note.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG, May 8 — The last couple of years have been exceedingly tough for the Movement for Democratic Change, the only opposition political party of any note in authoritarian Zimbabwe. Party officials have been beaten with stones and logs; their cars have been hijacked; their posters have been methodically stripped from street poles. In one memorable instance, thugs tried to toss the party’s director of security down a sixth-floor stairwell at its headquarters.
